title: Resources
text:
Welcome to the Yale School of Public Health Data Science and Data Equity (YSPH DSDE) Data Concierge site. This Data Concierge was established to support the mission of DSDE in reducing barriers to utilizing data science and AI in public health training, research, and practice.
Our mission is to develop and support a robust public health data science infrastructure that ensures secure and equitable data access and facilitates the translation of methodologies into user-friendly, open-source software tools and publicly available datasets. We strive to make high-quality public health resources accessible to all and foster an environment where data-driven decision-making can thrive.

title: Resources
text:
Navigating the Site
Explore our comprehensive collection of resources and datasets curated from international organizations, United States agencies, and Yale University that can support your public health research. Dataset listings come with detailed information on how to obtain the data, expected timelines for access and utilization, and examples of YSPH studies conducted and published using these specific datasets.

  
    
      
      National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS)

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text: Updated: September 2\(^{nd}\), 2025

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Overview
Surveillance of the dietary habits of the United States population began with the passage of the National Health Survey Act in 1956. Initially, the focus was on statistically measuring the extent, distribution, and impact of chronic illnesses, such as cardiovascular disease and diabetes, and disabilities through three National Health Examination Surveys (NHES). The latter two cycles of NHES focused on the growth and development of children and adolescents. In the early 1970s, this scope was expanded to include research into the connections between diet and diseases with the addition of the National Nutritional Surveillance System to NHES, forming NHANES 3,4.
This evolution included incorporating measurements that tracked changes in nutritional status over time, alongside clinical observations and professional assessments of survey participants. The NHANES survey underwent four changes until the protocol was settled in 1999 on the continuously conducted surveillance that is still carried out today 4.

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Programs
Throughout its various iterations, NHANES, and previously NHES from 1960 to 1970, have collected a range of surveys and metrics from differently sized and demographic samples of the U.S. population. While the types of data collected, such as interviews and physician examinations, have remained consistent since the program’s inception, the specific exams and tests have evolved over time. Additionally, the base population varied across iterations, with certain programs intentionally designed to oversample underrepresented ethnic and racial groups or vulnerable populations to enhance research possibilities for these groups.
All studies employed a multistage study design with stratified probability samples of loosely clustered individuals within land-based segments. Participants were randomly selected from primary sampling units (PSUs), which were further divided into segments based on geography, eligibility, and housing density. The designation of these PSUs varied with each iteration and was influenced by the intended base population for sampling inclusion. Sampling weights were generated in most iterations to reflect the national population of that stratification at the survey’s midpoint 5–8.
Results are available in the form of interviews, surveys, physician examinations, and laboratory results. In addition to baseline socioeconomic and demographic characteristics, data collection included anthropometric measurements, medical history, standard dental, vision, and audio exams, X-rays, and blood and urine analyte panels.


Special Focus Programs and Ancillary Studies
Most programs were intended to collect information about the United States population as a whole and its various subgroups, while sometimes oversampling age and income groups expected to be more vulnerable to malnutrition 8. The three NHES, often referred to as Cycles I-III, are essentially iterations of NHANES conducted separately to focus on specific age groups individually 9–11.
Throughout these programs, expert evaluation panels were assembled to assess NHANES’s ability to address key issues. Notably, the Hispanic Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (HHANES) (1982-84) was conducted as a complete NHANES iteration with the goal of improving representation among three significant U.S. Hispanic populations: Mexican-American, Cuban-American, and Puerto Rican communities 12,13.






Breaking Ground in Culture-Specific Research





The chapter dedicated to cross-cultural considerations, found in the Plan and Operation of HHANES documentation, acknowledged a need for cultural sensitivity and recognized unknown obstacles to implementation. It specifically noted that insufficient personnel on the core team were from or otherwise knowledgeable about the Hispanic population and cultures. This chapter highlighted that this was the first known attempt by the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) to conduct a survey focused on a specific ethnic group. This document details the strategies the team employed to address these shortcomings by hiring qualified personnel and forming task force committees intended to closely evaluate aspects of the program, from translation to survey content 13.



In some cases, this prompted the consolidation of existing NHANES and NHES research, the addition of programs to enhance representation, and the initiation of ancillary studies to address specific scientific inquiries not directly supported by the primary programs. Three examples of these initiatives are the Growth Chart (GROWTHCH) (1963-94), the NHANES Epidemiologic Followup Study (NHEFS) (1982-84, 1986, 1987, and 1992), and the NHANES National Youth Fitness Survey (NNYFS) (2012) 14–16.
Results from multiple follow-ups since the completion of NHANES III in 1994 are available as the NHANES III Augmented Data, Special Studies, and Surplus Sera Data. Some of these results include data generated by research groups through the NHANES Biospecimen program. All data produced with NHANES biospecimens are published as part of the ongoing list of follow-up studies. These projects cover a wide range of topics, including natality, spirometry, hipbone geometry, and sera data from surplus biospecimens 17.
Additional information about these special focus programs or ancillary studies can be found on the NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation webpage.


Note on Combined Data for Longitudinal Research
A researcher seeking to use this data will need to keep in mind that each survey iteration was conducted with specific differences, where some are more cross-comparable than others. More granular differences are summarized in the Historical NHANES Component Matrix, which compares NHANES programs up to 2006, and the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey: 1999–2022 Survey Content Brochure, which summarizes the annual continuous NHANES protocol differences. Additional information is also provided in the respective programs’ Survey Methods and Analytic Guidelines documentation or other manuals, accessible on the CDC landing page for each program 18,19.






Caution



One project plan for the Continuous NHANES was to allow for survey and content updates to meet emerging public health needs. It is challenging to comprehensively summarize each change made since 1999, as the program has been administered every two years since then. A generalized summary with highlights of major changes is provided in the table above.
Researchers interested in learning more about detailed protocol changes are encouraged to review the relevant documentation for each year available on the NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation webpage, the brochere linked above, or the NHANES Survey Methods and Analytic Guidelines webpage, which consolidates some of the program’s documentation 20,21.

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Gaining Access
Most of the data available through NHES, NHANES, and the ancillary programs is publicly available for those wishing to use it for statistical analysis and reporting purposes. Researchers seeking to use the data should review and become familiar with the terms and conditions of the NCHS Data User Agreement, which covers the use of any data available from their office 22.
Some of the more recent installments of the program offer additional levels of data with restricted access or provide researchers the option to generate their own data through the Biospecimen Program. Restricted data does not contain information that directly identifies participants, such as names, social security numbers, and addresses. However, it does include variables that could be used to identify participants when combined with other information, such as a person’s job or county of residence, and sensitive information.
Explore the information provided in the tabs below for details on access steps, limitations, and time expectations specific to the types of data you are seeking to acquire.

Publicly Available

Do I Qualify?
All persons seeking to use the data for statistical analysis and reporting purposes are allowed to access and download the data.


Step-by-Step Guide
There are no specific steps required. Simply navigate to the webpage with the NHANES program installment you want to use and download it. Be aware that specific considerations are needed to combine two different installments or biannual Continuous NHANES datasets. Refer to the relevant data documentation or any of the webinars and tutorials available for further directions on how to best handle survey design and protocol differences.


Typical Timeline
There are no time constraints for accessing these data.



Restrcited Access

Do I Qualify?
All individuals seeking to use the data for statistical analysis and reporting purposes are allowed to submit a research proposal to the NCHS Research Data Center (RDC) through the Standard Application Process (SAP) available through the ResearchDataGov (RDG) portal 23,24.
Applicants must fulfill the following criteria during the application review process, and in some cases, after application approval. These criteria are summarized from the RDG User Guide. If additional steps are required post-approval, the data-owning agency will contact you directly to initiate those processes.
Identification: Verify your identity, job title, organizational affiliation, and skill level. Some agencies require confirmation of U.S. citizenship.
Training: Some agencies require training on data use, data management, confidentiality, and cybersecurity following application approval.
Agreements: Sign agreements such as non-disclosure agreements or data use agreements. Some data sources may require the creation of a security plan outlining how the researcher will protect the data.
Investigation: Undergo a background check.


How Is My Application Assessed?
All applications submitted through SAP are evaluated against the same criteria, regardless of the agency or unit you are applying to for data, unless required by law or regulation. The full criteria are linked in the RDG User Guide, and summarized below 25:
Statistical Purpose: Data will be used solely for statistical purposes and not to identify individual persons or businesses, nor for law enforcement, legal cases, or regulatory actions.
Allowed Use: The researcher plans to use the data in compliance with the applicable rules and restrictions.
Statistical Disclosure Limitation: The researcher must be able to use techniques that protect the privacy of individuals, organizations, or businesses.
Demonstrated Need: The researcher must show that confidential data is necessary to support their project goals and that publicly available data is insufficient.
Feasibility: The researcher is able to achieve their project goals with the requested data. This is evaluated in three ways:


Project Design: Detailed methods planned and how the technical and logistical needs will be met.
Agency or Unit Support: Confirming beforehand that the agency can support the project through space, technical help, logistics, and preparation of the data.
Applicant Ability: The applicant has the knowledge, skills, and ability to carry out the project.


Maintaining Public Trust: The project is expected to help maintain the public’s trust and confidence in the agency or unit.
In addition to these criteria, the NCHS Review Committee will assess whether the study has a well-defined research question that addresses a public health concern, whether the results will benefit the agencies providing the data, and the appropriateness of the planned output from the study (e.g., paper, journal article, or presentation) 26.






Important



The NCHS will not evaluate your study to assess its scientific merit nor its substantive, methodological, theoretical, or policy relevance. It also does not provide guarantees that output generated by the study will be released contingent on concerns related, but not limited to, privacy and is in alignment with the approved application.




Typical Timeline

  
  Click on the image to view larger.




  ×
  
  



Upon receiving an application, your assigned RDC analyst and the review committee—comprising data system representatives and the confidentiality officer—will assess your application for approval, disapproval, or a request for revisions. If your application is denied by the committee, you will be provided with a justification for the decision. Researchers are allowed to request an appeal of the decision through SAP 27.
At some point, your study may require an amendment to the approved application. Approval for amendments typically take no more than four weeks, but can take as many as eight to twelve weeks if the amendment request is complicated.


Step-by-Step Guide
The RDG portal provides access to applications for data from 13 agencies and 3 units within the Federal Statistical System (FSS), including the NCHS. Each agency may have additional expectations for the application process that you will need to include if you are requesting data from them. While many details are available in the RDG User Guide or the RDC Application Process webpage (some of which are summarized here), researchers are advised to contact the agencies or units from which they are requesting data before submitting their application.
Example applications, data dictionaries, and complete details can be found on the RDC Application Process webpage 23. The summary provided here is intended solely to offer an outline and introduce you to the location of relevant information. You can reach the RDC directly at rdca@cdc.gov for further information 25.


Confirm that your study requires access to restricted data and that the data available through the FSS will meet your research needs. Contact all agencies or units responsible for the data to confirm that the data you need can be combined with all of the data required for your analysis, whether restricted-use, publicly available, or non-FSS.
NOTE: Data access methods and locations may vary, especially if the data comes from different agencies or units within the FSS.
Decide on your preferred location of access, and confirm that you are eligible to gain access at that location. If you are not a U.S. citizen, it is recommended that you reach out to the facility where you intend to access the data prior to writing your proposal. Refer to the Data Distribution Centers section below for further details.
The NCHS requires additional documents as *.pdf or *.docx and additional concerns to be addressed beyond the base SAP application. Before starting your application, it is recommended that you prepare the following:



A data dictionary listing all the requested variables from publicly available, restricted-use, and non-NCHS data sources. Much of this can be created in SAP. Refer to the Providing the Public Use and Non-NCHS Data webpage for additional guidelines on preparing your application with these types of data.
Description of the research methodology.
List of supporting references.
Detailed description of the intended data product (e.g., paper, journal article, or presentation).
Timeline for managing the project within a three-year period.
In the Agency Benefits section, you must demonstrate how your project will benefit NCHS or other agencies providing the data.
Determine and decide on your preferred access location.



In SAP, search for and select the datasets you need for your study, then add them to your basket. Any data added to the same basket will be included in a single application.
NOTE: You can add additional data to the application if needed after submission.
When you are ready to proceed with the application, open your basket and select Start Application. It is recommended that the principal investigator (PI) or co-principal investigator (co-PI) create the application, as only they will be able to make edits after submission.
In the application, you will need to provide researcher information, a description of the project that demonstrates the need for restricted-use data, and upload the required documents as *.pdf or *.docx. The standard SAP application and some agency- or unit-specific requirements can be found in the RDG User Guide.


Upon receiving the application, the RDC director will assign your group an RDC analyst who will work with you throughout the entire process of applying for data, accessing the data, and finalizing the output of your results 26. The RDC analyst will:


Facilitate the review of your application and accept your NCHS-required confidentiality paperwork.
Accept payments incurred by accessing the data at a data center.
Create your analytical dataset by compiling the data requested in the data dictionary and combining it based on the variables you assign for linking. This dataset will be provided to you when you visit a data center.
After you complete your analysis at a data center, they will review your output for disclosure risk and provide you with the results.


Approved applications must then complete the following steps in preparation to access and utilize the approved data.


Discuss the committee’s approval with your assigned RDC analyst and address any requests for revision as needed.
Provide the RDC analyst with the approved data dictionary, public-use and non-NCHS data, descriptions of desired data linkages with their intended final format, and clearly defined derived variables, including any arithmetic code or algorithms.
Complete the Confidentiality and Disclosure training and forms, and provide them to the RDC analyst. Additional forms, documents, and tools for this step can also be found on the RDC Reference Materials webpage 28,29.
When invoiced, you will need to pay the fees incurred by your request and applicable to accessing the data at your intended location and frequency of access. Refer to Fees and Invoicing for complete details 30.
Following completion of these steps, the RDC analyst will prepare your dataset. Once ready, set up an appointment to access the data at your chosen RDC location. Please schedule your appointment at least one week in advance.
NOTE: Different data centers have different procedures for gaining access and might incur additional fees depending on how frequently you intend to access the data. Refer to the Data Distribution Centers section and associated links for additional guidance.
After completing your analysis, you must submit an output request to your RDC analyst for review and approval. Find the full details about requirements and expectations on the Output Policies and Procedures webpage 31.
NOTE: The NCHS does not provide guarantees that output generated by the study will be released contingent on concerns related, but not limited to, privacy and is in alignment with the approved application.
When you have nearly completed your output, send it to your RDC analyst for review before submitting it for publication or distribution. Find the full details about requirements and expectations on the Publishing Guidelines webpage 32.








Important



Amendments for project changes are possible but require additional approval prior to implementation. Common reasons for an amendment include, but are not limited to, changes in the research team, requests for additional variables, new methods, or requests for additional types of output 23. However, if you wish to change the scope or research question, a new application is required instead.
Contact the RDC directly at rdca@cdc.gov for further guidance.




Data Distribution Centers
NCHS data is available at two types of data centers: the Census Bureau’s Federal Statistical Research Data Centers (FSRDC) and the NCHS Research Data Centers (RDCs). Additional details about preparing to access your data at one of these sites can be found on the RDC Location of Access webpage or their respective subpages: FSRDC and NCHS RDC 23,33–35.






Important



You must submit an electronic copy of any notes or reference materials you need to your RDC analyst prior to visiting a center. Hard copies of these materials are not allowed. You are also not allowed to bring electronic communication devices, such as phones, pagers, laptops, into the RDC.


You can request different software products or add-ons, though not all requests will be approved. Be aware that requesting additional software accommodations may delay the approval of your project. Contact the specific RDC where you plan to access your data for further guidance.

Federal Statistical Research Data Centers


You will be assigned both an NCHS RDC analyst and an FSRDC administrator from the location you intend to visit. Both have different roles.
Researchers must meet physical and information security requirements. They must obtain Census Bureau Special Sworn Status (SSS) and pass a background investigation.
You must be affiliated with a university or agency to qualify.
Non-U.S. citizens are generally encouraged to use FSRDCs.
In-person: Census Bureau facilities at partner institutions.
Remote access: A secure Virtual Desktop Interface (VDI) may be available.
Software Available: Anaconda, Gurobi, Intel Composer, Knittro, MADD, Mathematica, NATLAB, OpenGeoda, R and Rstudio, SAS, Stat/Transfer, Stata, Stata-MP, SUDAAN, and Tomlab.








Important



If you are accessing an FSRDC, the data must be transferred from NCHS after completing all requirements outlined by your assigned RDC analyst seven days prior to your intended visit. These additional steps incur extra costs beyond the NCHS RDC data access fee and may delay data access.


Previously, the roles of RDC analysts were listed. The FSRDC, or Census RDC, administrator will:


Be available to answer questions pertaining to SSS, access and entry to a FSRDC location, software availability, and additional, Census fees.
They may be available to help develop your application.
Transfer your output to the NCHS after you complete your analysis at a data center. Your RDC analyst will review your output for disclosure risk and provide you with the results.




NCHS Research Data Centers


In-person: Facilities are located in Hyattsville, MD, Atlanta, GA, and Rockville, MD and are accessible by appointment only at least one week in advance.
Remote access: The computers are not connected to the internet, so remote access is not possible.
Software Available: Microsoft Office products, R, SAS, Stata, Python, SPSS (v. 19), and SAS-callable SUDAAN.




Required Documentation
When accessing the data, the researcher will need to provide the following documentation in addition to an approved application:


Proof of identification, such as a REAL ID.
Curriculum vitae (CV) for each applicant.
For student projects, the student’s advisor must provide an agreement form.
Permission to use proprietary data.
Requested output must include Table Shells.
Requested variables must be provided in a data dictionary format that lists all necessary variables (i.e., restricted-use, public-use, and external) for the research project. Please refer to the agency dataset data dictionaries for the available variables.

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Valuable Links


NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation: Find links to all installments or ancillary studies and the programs methods and oterh documentation 20.
NCHS Data User Agreement: Find the data use limitations and expectations set by the NCHS for using their publicly available data 22.
Confidentiality and Disclosure: Find the study participant confidentiality training, documentation, forms, and manual 29. Completion of these trainings and forms is required following the approval of your study proposal by the research committee.
Application Process: Find the complete step-by-step guide to applying for restricted use data from the RDC 23. Some of this information has been summarized for your convenience under the Gaining Access - Restricted Access tab.
RDC Reference Materials: Find restricted-use data proposals, example applications, confidentiality and disclosure documents, rules, policies, and data protection toolkits 28.
NHANES Biospecimen Program: Find the request forms for DNA, serum, plasma, and urine samples as well as genetic data produced from the NHANES biospeciments 36.
NHANES Webinars: Find additional information and resources for program partners and data users, including updates and survey strategies 37.
NHANES Tutorials: Find help understanding sample design, variance estimation, interpreting documentation with example analyses, software tips, and sample code 38.
What NHANES Data Have Achieved: Find a listing of the public health research inspired by NHANES data and the policy changes it has influenced 2.

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Publications
This section displays PubMed articles that mention the dataset and are authored by individuals affiliated with the Yale School of Public Health. Please note that the PubMed API does not distinguish between uppercase and lowercase characters when processing queries. As a result, there may be occasional mismatches in the search results.

Through its different iterations, NHANES, and previously NHES from 1960 to 1970, collected various surveys and metrics from differently sized and demographic samplings of the U.S. population. A researcher seeking to use this data will need to keep in mind that each survey iteration was conducted with specific differences, where some are more cross-comparable than others. We briefly discuss these differences here, but additional methadological variations can be found by reviewing the references provided below.

Methods and Representational Differences
The following table summarizes critical program features and highlights changes or differences between each program iteration. Although the data types, such as interviews and physician examinations, have remained consistent since the program’s inception, the kinds and scope of exams and tests have changed. The base population also varied, with certain programs intentionally designed to oversample underrepresented ethnic and racial groups or vulnerable populations to improve research possibilities for these groups.
We do not spend time distinguishing methodological differences if the same type of exam was conducted with different instruments or protocols. Researchers interested in learning more about these granular differences to assess the possibility of cross-program compatibility are recommended to review the Historical NHANES Component Matrix, which compares NHANES programs up to 2006, and the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey: 1999–2022 Survey Content Brochure, which summarizes the annual continuous NHANES protocol differences. Additional information is also provided in the respective programs’ Survey Methods and Analytic Guidelines documentation or other manuals, accessible on the CDC landing page for each program 5,6.

Continuous NHANES 24


 Dates: Every two years since 1999   Study Design: A similar strategy to NHANES I was employed. For each two-year cycle, approximately 30 counties out of the 3,000 PSU counties were selected, ensuring that each of the four regions of the United States, as well as both metropolitan and nonmetropolitan areas, were represented each time 3. The notable exceptions to this continuity are the 2019-20 and 2021-23 cycles 25,26.   Data Types: 18,22

To learn more about both, navigate to the respective data release year accessible from the main NHANES Questionnaires, Data, and Related Documentation webpage.   NOTE: Generally speaking, any 2-year data cycle in Continuous NHANES can be combined with adjacent 2-year data cycles utilizing the same sampling design to create analytic data files based on 4 or more years of data, allowing for greater precision. Protocols are provided in respective documentation to provide direction on how to best combine historical Continuous NHANES data with more current iterations.   NOTE: Due to the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, the 2019-20 Continuous NHANES series was suspended in March 2020. Consequently, only 18 of 30 PSUs were recorded, rendering the sample not nationally representative. To compensate, the 2017-March 2020 Pre-pandemic dataset was created. Users should be aware that combining these programs introduces new challenges due to differences in sampling methods and time spans. For additional details, refer to the 2017–March 2020 Prepandemic File: Sample Design, Estimation, and Analytic Guidelines for additional details 27.

 Oversampling 1999-06: Non-Hispanic black persons, Mexican-American persons, low-income white persons beginning in 2000 (at or below 130% of the federal poverty line), adolescents aged 12–19, and persons aged 70 years and over. A supplemental sample of pregnant women was also included, but they were not an oversampled group 3.   Oversampling 2007-10: Non-Hispanic black persons, Hispanic persons, low-income persons (at or below 130% of the federal poverty line), persons aged 80 years and over 3.   Oversampling 2011-14: The same groups as the 2007-10 study design with non-Hispanic non-back Asian persons 30.   Oversampling 2015-18: The same groups as the 2011-14 study design with low-income persons determined at or below 185% of the federal poverty line and persons 0-11 years old 29.   Oversampling 2019-20: The original design included the same groups as the 2011-14 study design without the 0-11 years old group. Due to the premature suspension of operations in March 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the data are not nationally representative on their own. These data are available as a convenience sample 25.   Oversampling 2021-23: Efforts to limit participant and staff exposure to COVID-19 led to modifications in every aspect of study design and sampling. To reduce the number of dwellings visited, there was no oversampling of racial or socioeconomic groups. Households with any individuals aged 0–19 years and 60 and older were eligible to participate, while not everyone aged 20–59 years from the same household was included 26. 











Caution





One project plan for the Continuous NHANES was to allow for survey and content updates to meet emerging public health needs. It is challenging to comprehensively summarize each change made since 1999, as the program has been administered every two years since then. A generalized summary with highlights of major changes is provided in the table above.
Researchers interested in learning more about detailed protocol changes are encouraged to review the relevant documentation for each year available on the NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation webpage, the brochere linked above, or the NHANES Survey Methods and Analytic Guidelines webpage, which consolidates some of the program’s documentation 24,31.





Special Focus Programs and Ancillary Studies
Most programs were intended to collect information about the United States population as a whole and its various subgroups, while sometimes oversampling age and income groups expected to be more vulnerable to malnutrition 16. The three NHES, often referred to as Cycles I-III, are essentially iterations of NHANES conducted separately to focus on specific age groups individually 7,10,12. Throughout these programs, expert evaluation panels were assembled to assess NHANES’s ability to address key issues 20.
In some cases, this warranted the consolidation of existing NHANES and NHES research, the addition of programs to enhance representation, and ancillary studies to address specific scientific inquiries not directly supported by the primary programs. These are summarized below, and additional information can be found on the NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation webpage.

Hispanic Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (HHANES) 1982-84
After the completion of NHANES II in 1980, an expert panel recommended that the next program focus on the health and nutritional status of a specific subpopulation. Different groups were considered, and it was determined that the Hispanic population should be the focus due to notable gaps in comparable data for this population. This was partly due to insufficient representation of Hispanic populations and a lack of separate representation for Mexican-American, Cuban-American, and Puerto Rican communities. HHANES was formulated with the explicit purpose of supporting estimations of the health and nutritional status of the United States Hispanic population so that it is comparable with the general population, while also considering variations between these three specific Hispanic communities 20.
Additional study design and content details are provided earlier in the Methods and Representational Differences section.






Note





The chapter dedicated to cross-cultural considerations, found in the Plan and Operation of HHANES documentation, acknowledged a need for cultural sensitivity and recognized unknown obstacles to implementation. It specifically noted that insufficient personnel on the core team were from or otherwise knowledgeable about the Hispanic population and cultures. This chapter highlighted that this was the first known attempt by the National Center for Health Statistics (NCHS) to conduct a survey focused on a specific ethnic group. This document details the strategies the team employed to address these shortcomings by hiring qualified personnel and forming task force committees intended to closely evaluate aspects of the program, from translation to survey content 20.

title: National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey
text:
Gaining Access
Most of the data available through NHES, NHANES, and the ancillary programs is freely accessible for those wishing to use it for statistical analysis and reporting purposes. Researchers seeking to use the data should review and become familiar with the terms and conditions of the NCHS Data User Agreement, which covers the use of any data available from their office 40.
Some of the more recent installments of the program offer additional levels of data with restricted access or provide researchers the option to generate their own data through the Biospecimen Program. Restricted data does not contain information that directly identifies participants, such as names, social security numbers, and addresses. However, it does include variables that could be used to identify participants when combined with other information, such as a person’s job or county of residence, and sensitive information.
Explore the information provided in the tabs below for details on access steps, limitations, and time expectations specific to the types of data you are seeking to acquire.

Freely AccessibleRestrcited Access



Do I Qualify?
All persons seeking to use the data for statistical analysis and reporting purposes are allowed to access and download the data.


Step-by-Step Guide
There are no specific steps required. Simply navigate to the webpage with the NHANES program installment you want to use and download it. Be aware that specific considerations are needed to combine two different installments or biannual Continuous NHANES datasets. Refer to the relevant data documentation or any of the webinars and tutorials available for further directions on how to best handle survey design and protocol differences.


Typical Timeline
There are no time constraints for accessing these data.




Do I Qualify?
All individuals seeking to use the data for statistical analysis and reporting purposes are allowed to submit a research proposal to the NCHS Research Data Center (RDC) through the Standard Application Process (SAP) available through the ResearchDataGov (RDG) portal 41,42.
Applicants must fulfill the following criteria during the application review process, and in some cases, after application approval. These criteria are summarized from the RDG User Guide. If additional steps are required post-approval, the data-owning agency will contact you directly to initiate those processes.
Identification: Verify your identity, job title, organizational affiliation, and skill level. Some agencies require confirmation of U.S. citizenship.
Training: Some agencies require training on data use, data management, confidentiality, and cybersecurity following application approval.
Agreements: Sign agreements such as non-disclosure agreements or data use agreements. Some data sources may require the creation of a security plan outlining how the researcher will protect the data.
Investigation: Undergo a background check.


How Is My Application Assessed?
All applications submitted through SAP are evaluated against the same criteria, regardless of the agency or unit you are applying to for data, unless required by law or regulation. The full criteria are linked in the RDG User Guide, and summarized below 43:
Statistical Purpose: Data will be used solely for statistical purposes and not to identify individual persons or businesses, nor for law enforcement, legal cases, or regulatory actions.
Allowed Use: The researcher plans to use the data in compliance with the applicable rules and restrictions.
Statistical Disclosure Limitation: The researcher must be able to use techniques that protect the privacy of individuals, organizations, or businesses.
Demonstrated Need: The researcher must show that confidential data is necessary to support their project goals and that publicly available data is insufficient.
Feasibility: The researcher is able to achieve their project goals with the requested data. This is evaluated in three ways:


Project Design: Detailed methods planned and how the technical and logistical needs will be met.
Agency or Unit Support: Confirming beforehand that the agency can support the project through space, technical help, logistics, and preparation of the data.
Applicant Ability: The applicant has the knowledge, skills, and ability to carry out the project.


Maintaining Public Trust: The project is expected to help maintain the public’s trust and confidence in the agency or unit.
In addition to these criteria, the NCHS Review Committee will assess whether the study has a well-defined research question that addresses a public health concern, whether the results will benefit the agencies providing the data, and the appropriateness of the planned output from the study (e.g., paper, journal article, or presentation) 44.






Important



The NCHS will not evaluate your study to assess its scientific merit nor its substantive, methodological, theoretical, or policy relevance. It also does not provide guarantees that output generated by the study will be released contingent on concerns related, but not limited to, privacy and is in alignment with the approved application.




Typical Timeline

  
  Click on the image to view larger.




  ×
  
  



Upon receiving an application, your assigned RDC analyst and the review committee—comprising data system representatives and the confidentiality officer—will assess your application for approval, disapproval, or a request for revisions. If your application is denied by the committee, you will be provided with a justification for the decision. Researchers are allowed to request an appeal of the decision through SAP 45.
At some point, your study may require an amendment to the approved application. Approval for amendments typically take no more than four weeks, but can take as many as eight to twelve weeks if the amendment request is complicated.


Step-by-Step Guide
The RDG portal provides access to applications for data from 13 agencies and 3 units within the Federal Statistical System (FSS), including the NCHS. Each agency may have additional expectations for the application process that you will need to include if you are requesting data from them. While many details are available in the RDG User Guide or the RDC Application Process webpage (some of which are summarized here), researchers are advised to contact the agencies or units from which they are requesting data before submitting their application.
Example applications, data dictionaries, and complete details can be found on the RDC Application Process webpage 41. The summary provided here is intended solely to offer an outline and introduce you to the location of relevant information. You can reach the RDC directly at rdca@cdc.gov for further information 43.


Confirm that your study requires access to restricted data and that the data available through the FSS will meet your research needs. Contact all agencies or units responsible for the data to confirm that the data you need can be combined with all of the data required for your analysis, whether restricted-use, publicly available, or non-FSS.
NOTE: Data access methods and locations may vary, especially if the data comes from different agencies or units within the FSS.
Decide on your preferred location of access, and confirm that you are eligible to gain access at that location. If you are not a U.S. citizen, it is recommended that you reach out to the facility where you intend to access the data prior to writing your proposal. Refer to the Data Distribution Centers section below for further details.
The NCHS requires additional documents as *.pdf or *.docx and additional concerns to be addressed beyond the base SAP application. Before starting your application, it is recommended that you prepare the following:



A data dictionary listing all the requested variables from publicly available, restricted-use, and non-NCHS data sources. Much of this can be created in SAP. Refer to the Providing the Public Use and Non-NCHS Data webpage for additional guidelines on preparing your application with these types of data.
Description of the research methodology.
List of supporting references.
Detailed description of the intended data product (e.g., paper, journal article, or presentation).
Timeline for managing the project within a three-year period.
In the Agency Benefits section, you must demonstrate how your project will benefit NCHS or other agencies providing the data.
Determine and decide on your preferred access location.



In SAP, search for and select the datasets you need for your study, then add them to your basket. Any data added to the same basket will be included in a single application.
NOTE: You can add additional data to the application if needed after submission.
When you are ready to proceed with the application, open your basket and select Start Application. It is recommended that the principal investigator (PI) or co-principal investigator (co-PI) create the application, as only they will be able to make edits after submission.
In the application, you will need to provide researcher information, a description of the project that demonstrates the need for restricted-use data, and upload the required documents as *.pdf or *.docx. The standard SAP application and some agency- or unit-specific requirements can be found in the RDG User Guide.


Upon receiving the application, the RDC director will assign your group an RDC analyst who will work with you throughout the entire process of applying for data, accessing the data, and finalizing the output of your results 44. The RDC analyst will:


Facilitate the review of your application and accept your NCHS-required confidentiality paperwork.
Accept payments incurred by accessing the data at a data center.
Create your analytical dataset by compiling the data requested in the data dictionary and combining it based on the variables you assign for linking. This dataset will be provided to you when you visit a data center.
After you complete your analysis at a data center, they will review your output for disclosure risk and provide you with the results.


Approved applications must then complete the following steps in preparation to access and utilize the approved data.


Discuss the committee’s approval with your assigned RDC analyst and address any requests for revision as needed.
Provide the RDC analyst with the approved data dictionary, public-use and non-NCHS data, descriptions of desired data linkages with their intended final format, and clearly defined derived variables, including any arithmetic code or algorithms.
Complete the Confidentiality and Disclosure training and forms, and provide them to the RDC analyst. Additional forms, documents, and tools for this step can also be found on the RDC Reference Materials webpage 46,47.
When invoiced, you will need to pay the fees incurred by your request and applicable to accessing the data at your intended location and frequency of access. Refer to Fees and Invoicing for complete details 48.
Following completion of these steps, the RDC analyst will prepare your dataset. Once ready, set up an appointment to access the data at your chosen RDC location. Please schedule your appointment at least one week in advance.
NOTE: Different data centers have different procedures for gaining access and might incur additional fees depending on how frequently you intend to access the data. Refer to the Data Distribution Centers section and associated links for additional guidance.
After completing your analysis, you must submit an output request to your RDC analyst for review and approval. Find the full details about requirements and expectations on the Output Policies and Procedures webpage 49.
NOTE: The NCHS does not provide guarantees that output generated by the study will be released contingent on concerns related, but not limited to, privacy and is in alignment with the approved application.
When you have nearly completed your output, send it to your RDC analyst for review before submitting it for publication or distribution. Find the full details about requirements and expectations on the Publishing Guidelines webpage 50.








Important



Amendments for project changes are possible but require additional approval prior to implementation. Common reasons for an amendment include, but are not limited to, changes in the research team, requests for additional variables, new methods, or requests for additional types of output 41. However, if you wish to change the scope or research question, a new application is required instead.
Contact the RDC directly at rdca@cdc.gov for further guidance.




Data Distribution Centers
NCHS data is available at two types of data centers: the Census Bureau’s Federal Statistical Research Data Centers (FSRDC) and the NCHS Research Data Centers (RDCs). Additional details about preparing to access your data at one of these sites can be found on the RDC Location of Access webpage or their respective subpages: FSRDC and NCHS RDC 41,51–53.






Important



You must submit an electronic copy of any notes or reference materials you need to your RDC analyst prior to visiting a center. Hard copies of these materials are not allowed. You are also not allowed to bring electronic communication devices, such as phones, pagers, laptops, into the RDC.


You can request different software products or add-ons, though not all requests will be approved. Be aware that requesting additional software accommodations may delay the approval of your project. Contact the specific RDC where you plan to access your data for further guidance.

Federal Statistical Research Data Centers


You will be assigned both an NCHS RDC analyst and an FSRDC administrator from the location you intend to visit. Both have different roles.
Researchers must meet physical and information security requirements. They must obtain Census Bureau Special Sworn Status (SSS) and pass a background investigation.
You must be affiliated with a university or agency to qualify.
Non-U.S. citizens are generally encouraged to use FSRDCs.
In-person: Census Bureau facilities at partner institutions.
Remote access: A secure Virtual Desktop Interface (VDI) may be available.
Software Available: Anaconda, Gurobi, Intel Composer, Knittro, MADD, Mathematica, NATLAB, OpenGeoda, R and Rstudio, SAS, Stat/Transfer, Stata, Stata-MP, SUDAAN, and Tomlab.








Important



If you are accessing an FSRDC, the data must be transferred from NCHS after completing all requirements outlined by your assigned RDC analyst seven days prior to your intended visit. These additional steps incur extra costs beyond the NCHS RDC data access fee and may delay data access.


Previously, the roles of RDC analysts were listed. The FSRDC, or Census RDC, administrator will:


Be available to answer questions pertaining to SSS, access and entry to a FSRDC location, software availability, and additional, Census fees.
They may be available to help develop your application.
Transfer your output to the NCHS after you complete your analysis at a data center. Your RDC analyst will review your output for disclosure risk and provide you with the results.




NCHS Research Data Centers


In-person: Facilities are located in Hyattsville, MD, Atlanta, GA, and Rockville, MD and are accessible by appointment only at least one week in advance.
Remote access: The computers are not connected to the internet, so remote access is not possible.
Software Available: Microsoft Office products, R, SAS, Stata, Python, SPSS (v. 19), and SAS-callable SUDAAN.




Required Documentation
When accessing the data, the researcher will need to provide the following documentation in addition to an approved application:


Proof of identification, such as a REAL ID.
Curriculum vitae (CV) for each applicant.
For student projects, the student’s advisor must provide an agreement form.
Permission to use proprietary data.
Requested output must include Table Shells.
Requested variables must be provided in a data dictionary format that lists all necessary variables (i.e., restricted-use, public-use, and external) for the research project. Please refer to the agency dataset data dictionaries for the available variables.

NHANES Questionnaires, Datasets, and Related Documentation: Find links to all installments or ancillary studies and the programs methods and oterh documentation 24.

Confidentiality and Disclosure: Find the study participant confidentiality training, documentation, forms, and manual 47. Completion of these trainings and forms is required following the approval of your study proposal by the research committee.
Application Process: Find the complete step-by-step guide to applying for restricted use data from the RDC 41. Some of this information has been summarized for your convenience under the Gaining Access - Restricted Access tab.
RDC Reference Materials: Find restricted-use data proposals, example applications, confidentiality and disclosure documents, rules, policies, and data protection toolkits 46.
NHANES Biospecimen Program: Find the request forms for DNA, serum, plasma, and urine samples as well as genetic data produced from the NHANES biospeciments 54.
NHANES Webinars: Find additional information and resources for program partners and data users, including updates and survey strategies 55.
NHANES Tutorials: Find help understanding sample design, variance estimation, interpreting documentation with example analyses, software tips, and sample code 56.
What NHANES Data Have Achieved: Find a listing of the public health research inspired by NHANES data and the policy changes it has influenced 2.

title: Yale New Haven Health System (YNHHS) Epic  and Epic Cosmos
text:
Researchers wanting to use the Yale New Haven Health System (YNHHS) Epic and Epic Cosmos data will need a Researcher Basic Access (RBA) account. Qualifying researchers will receive a YNHHS NetID and Duo Access, which affords access to:


Virtual Desktop Infrastructure (VDI)



Epic SlicerDicer







Computational Health Platform (CHP)







Microsoft Office 365



Remote access to a YNHHS secure device without requiring the YNHHS VPN. VDI includes the following software: SQL Server Management Studio, R, Stata, SAS, Office365, and Epic. It can be used to handle small-to-medium sized data, accessing Epic charts, SlicerDicer, and the Computational Health Platform (CHP).
Access de-identified summary count data representing the entire YNHHS patient dataset for data exploration, analytics, and reporting. Institutional Review Board (IRB) applications are not required to access de-identified data, but training is strongly recommended before usage.
Researchers can request access to the Epic Cosmos system, which will provide de-identified, summary count data for all participating Epic systems outside of YNHHS.
A secure, compliant, and collaborative high-performance computing cluster specifically designed for clinical data analysis. Suitable for AI research and development, and is well suited for analyzing large volumes of data in different forms (i.e. images, text, structured).
This tool requires advanced data science skills with relational databases, Python, and SQL. Additional details can be found here: OMOP Common Data Model.
Microsoft applications linked within the YNHHS organization.


There are three levels of access available:


RBA without an IRB give access to the afore mentioned resources but only supplies de-identified, summary count data produced within YNHHS Epic.
RBA with an approved IRB gives access to individual-level data for Epic data produced within YNHHS that is strictly relevant to the IRB approved study.
Epic Cosmos - RBA holders can gain access to de-identified, summary count data produced by Epic participating institutions outside of YNHHS upon special request.




All Yale University and YNHHS (YU-YNHHS) Covered Entity faculty and licensed provider may submit and sponsor RBA requests. If you are within the Yale system, your manager or sponser with a YNHHS account must complete the “YNHHS Researcher Basic Access” request on your behalf to start the process.
If you are not a member of a YU-YNHHS Covered Entity (e.g. YSPH), you will need a sponsor to submit a request on your behalf. Find the current “List of Covered Departments” under “Administrative Functions” on the hippa.yale.edu resources page.

title: Yale New Haven Health System (YNHHS) Epic  and Epic Cosmos
text:
Step-by-Step


Your YU-YNHHS Covered Entity manager or sponsor will complete the “YNHHS Researcher Basic Access” request on your behalf. This will give you YNHHS log-in credentials and identification authentication with Duo.
For Yale NetID holders: HIPAA Privacy and Security courses in Workday, including the basic privacy and security module followed by the role specific module (i.e. for clinician’s or researcher’s).
For Non-Yale NetID holders: read and sign the HIPAA Privacy and Security training materials specific to your role on the project (i.e. for clinician’s or researcher’s). Submission directions for these documents can be found on the PDF.
Human Subjects Protection Training (HSPT) certificate from CITI that has been completed within the last 3 years. Below is a summary of the process and the complete directions can be found on the It’s Your Yale page about HSPT. You can reach out to irb.training@yale.edu for further questions.
Researchers will need to complete the following CITI certificates:



“Basic Training”
One of the following two initial/basic Human Subjects Research modules: “Biomedical Research Basic” or “Social Behavioral Educational Researchers Basic”.



For Yale-affiliates, it is preferable, though not required, to go through Workday to access the CITI training modules. Doing so will expedite recognition of the certificate in the Yale Integrated Research Enterprise Solution (IRES) IRB system. In Workday, the CITI training link will show up as the “Human Subjects Protection Training – Initial/Refresher” course. You can reach out to your manager, learning@yale.edu, or irb.training@yale.edu to request manual assignment if needed.
Qualifying certificates completed through other institutions CITI subscriptions need to be emailed to irb.training@yale.edu. Please keep in mind that receiving CITI certification independently from a subscribing institution will incur charges.


SlicerDicer

title: About Us
text:
Public Health Data Science and Data Equity (DSDE) aims to strategically support and elevate data science training, education, research and collaboration efforts at the Yale School of Public Health (YSPH) and promote data equity as a fundamental pillar of health equity.
We aim to:

title: About Us
text:
Other Things We Do
Building upon our core missions, DSDE is deeply committed to a spectrum of activities designed to foster innovation, collaboration, and leadership in the field of public health and epidemiology. Our efforts include a broad range of resources, events, and services that collectively contribute to the advancement of equitous, trustworthy, and impactful research in public health.
Each resource is designed to empower YSPH students, staff, and faculty to excel in public health data science. Whenever possible, we democratize our resources to ensure that public health professionals and researchers globally can benefit from and contribute to our collective mission of advancing public health data science and promoting data equity.






  
    
      
      Other Resources
    
    
      In addition to the Resource Navigation Tool, DSDE has curated and consolidated software developed by faculty and students at the school of public health and hosts various events geared towards accelerating impactful data-driven discoveries.
      Find Out More
      
    
  





  
    
      
      Services
    
    
      We directly support Yale researchers through consulting and contracting. We offer an array of services, including statistical analysis, data vsualization, implementation of AI/ML, R package development, dashboarding, and custom workshops/tutorials.
      Find Out More
      
    
  





  
    
      
      Educational Materials and Events
    
    
      As part of our mission to strengthen data science and analytical literacy in the next generation of public health leaders, DSDE hosts a variety of educational events, including our Coffee, Cookies, and Coding (C-cubed) workshops.
      Find Out More
      
    
  









    People
    DSDE is a collaborative community driving the future of equitable public health at Yale. Below are some of the people on the team who contributed to the Resource Navigation Tool. You can find out more about the whole team on our main YSPH webpage.





  
  Resources with Features
  


  
    
      
        
          
            
          
          
            Bhramar Mukherjee, PhD
            Senior Associate Dean of Public Health Data Science and Data Equity; Anna M.R.             Professor Bhramar Mukherjee is the Anna M.R. Lauder Professor of Biostatistics and Professor of Chronic Disease Epidemiology at the Yale School of Public Health (YSPH). Professor Mukherjee serves as the inaugural Senior Associate Dean of Public Health Data Science and Data Equity at YSPH. She holds a secondary appointment in the Department of Statistics and Data Science and is affiliated with the MacMillan Center and the Institute for the Foundations of Data Science. She serves on the Yale Cancer Center Director’s cabinet.
